title: When do you use 'I'm upset at you' or 'I'm upset with you'? - Quora

response.answer_text: well, this isn’t only an answer about the language barrier, its an thought directed at boundary setting, or epressing your emotions with someone. it could be said that the first phrase is somewhat provocative, insinuating the person you are speaking with is at fault. in actual fact, so is the second answer. perhaps you might consider simply, “I’m upset.” without assigning blame to it. perhaps it would be a more harmonious and peaceful conversation which ensues. :), in either language, it’s a healthierstart to a positive resolution.
